data.meta_description: Just a French guy spreading his chaos and madness
data.text:
The theme park Bonbon Land has a ride called Beaver Rafting that has a strong American wilderness/national parks theme with stuff like the Mount Rushmore heads replaced with the parks oldest mascots

And the Niagara Falls

But at the entrance where you get on they have this statue of their owl mascot

And it was during my last visit with my family I realized it‚Äôs a reference to this fucking thing

The Bohemian Grove owl that American politicians love and conspiracy nuts hate.

They might as well have made an All Seeing Eye reference but this is so much more obscure and feels like an easter egg just for people like me because most Danes aren‚Äôt going to know what the hell that is.

My favourite aspect of fandom by far is it‚Äôs ability to just take one look at any new piece of material and go ‚Äúthanks, but no thanks‚Äù, and utterly ignore the brand new canon information.

Don‚Äôt like a character? Easy, they never existed!

New movie/episode is trash? Don‚Äôt worry, it was a character‚Äôs fever dream the whole time!

Your fav died? That was just a hallucination of their loved ones while they‚Äôre in the hospital, they‚Äôll be fine!

The ability of fandom to completely rewrite material is utterly amazing. The collective willpower and spite we wield at all times.

And on the flipside there is this mass effect of people choosing to rewrite material just because they don‚Äôt like it or want to do it ‚Äútheir way‚Äù, which, from a creator‚Äôs point of view, is absolutely terrifying.

I keep seeing everybody talk about the ‚Äúgood‚Äù examples there of people dealing with crappy endings or bad episodes or characters ‚Äúout of character‚Äù. But I rarely see people talk of the ‚Äúbad‚Äù examples - the negative interpretations, the harmful rewrites, the offensive takes, people literaly telling creators ‚ÄúYou have absolutely no influence and no decision-making over this character or world or story you created. They‚Äôre not yours. They‚Äôre ours. And we don‚Äôt care if you meant to say something, we will see what we want to see.‚Äù

(The most recent example I can think of being the ‚ÄúDiscworld books are anti-trans‚Äù take, but that‚Äôs a tiny water-drop compared to even more dangerous or repulsive stuff).

Sorry for hijacking the post, but it is something that haunts me and that I will always need to tell. And it is the reason why I hate fandoms. They literaly take what is not theirs and what they had no input into creating, and claim they are the makers of things and their word has more value.

I am all for interpretation, reinterpretation, twists, and AUs and whatnot. But I do believe that some people lack the media awareness and artistic culture needed to just approach simple concepts such as ‚ÄúWe are an audience criticizing a work. They are the creators of the work. We are not on the same level.‚Äù

Once I would have agreed that this sounds pedantic and arrogant. But I see how fandoms behave and act on the Internet, and how immature and baffling it all becomes (doesn‚Äôt help most of them are literal kids, the age of Internet users dropped terrifyingly), and I realize that, sadly, yes, a lot of the pedantic people had something right.

SPECIFIC MOVIE RECOMMENDATIONS #1

üåô‚ú® Gothic Fairy-Tale Films with Strong Female Leads ‚ú®üåô

üçí‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüî•Hey lovelies,

If you're like me find endless inspiration in the aesthetics of gothic fairy-tales, then you're in for a treat! I've created a list of enchanting atmospheric films, perfect for a cozy evening with your favorite tea.

To start with, of course, an absolute classic: a folk horror, menstrual tale with possibly the most aesthetically beautiful frames I've ever experienced in cinema. I constantly post something from this film on my blogs.

Valerie and Her Week of Wonders (1970): This surreal Czechoslovakian film follows young Valerie as she discovers a dreamlike world filled with vampires and magic. It's a visually stunning exploration of adolescence and awakening womanhood.

2. Daughters of Darkness (1971): This cult classic Belgian horror film features a mysterious, seductive countess who preys on young lovers in a deserted hotel. it‚Äôs a hypnotic blend of gothic allure and vampiric intrigue.

3. Nosferatu the Vampyre (1979): Werner Herzog's remake of the classic silent version. The film captures the gothic essence with stunning visuals and a chilling, melancholic tone. It's a mesmerizing exploration of fear and beauty.

4. The Vampire Lovers (1970): This Hammer Horror classic stars Ingrid Pitt as the alluring vampire Carmilla, who preys on young women in a secluded 19th-century village. it‚Äôs a captivating blend of horror and sensuality.

5. Beauty and the Beast (1978): This dark fantasy film, directed by Juraj Herz, offers a unique and eerie retelling of the classic fairy tale.Ideal for those who love a blend of dark romance and fairy-tale magic.

6. Viy (1967): This Soviet horror film, based on Nikolai Gogol's novella, follows a young priest who must spend three nights watching over the body of a witch in a haunted church. With its eerie atmosphere, stunning special effects, and deep roots in Slavic folklore, it's a captivating blend of supernatural horror and gothic fantasy.

That's all for today. I have many more films like these saved on my watchlist, so once I find some gems, I'll make another list. You can also look forward to a list of my favorite old fairy tales adaptations.

Kisses üíåüíå

For people who like to make up different races of the same fantasy creatures like forest elf and dark elf and such, you‚Äôd have traditional Scandinavian folklore on your side if you made merpeople in the north have a sexual dimorphism where mermen are smaller than mermaids.

For some reason mermen are always described as being about the size of a child in early folklore. They‚Äôre absurdly easy to catch and people in the stories tend to take them home and keep them for a while because mermen could predict the weather. The merman eventually dies or tricks his captors into taking him back to the sea. So opposite mermaids who lured and drowned people mermen were considered pretty harmless and even useful if caught.
